Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello Sebastian and Julian,

First of all, I think this game is a great ide=
a and an impressive result!
It is one of those ideas that I always wanted t=
o try, to test wether it is
fun to play and to see what kind of innovations=
 might be produced in the
hands of a large player base, but I never felt I =
had enough time,
experience or motivation to start development.

As for my =
experience playing the game, I think the tutorial messages were
very good, =
but I couldn't shake the feeling of being a bit lost on the
brain training =
screen. I mean, the game told me that I should evolve a
brain to follow and=
 a brain to flee, but during training I got little
feedback on if I was doi=
ng things right or not. Maybe it would help if you
could select a target be=
havior during training such that the game could
give you better feedback on=
 your progress.

Also, despite the tooltips, some of the objectives weren't=
 very clear to
me. For example, I am not sure what the exact difference is =
between keeping
a certain distance and reaching a certain distance, nor how=
 exactly this
interacts with the '- Distance' slider. For example, I assume=
d that keeping
a distance of 1 meter would cause the robots to drive toward=
s the target
and stop at 1 meter distance, but looking at the results and n=
umbers during
evolution I am really not sure if that is true. Another examp=
le is the
'move around' objective. When I tried to evolve a brain that woul=
d stand
still and do nothing I set the 'move around' slider to -100. When I=
 ran
evolution, rather than standing still the robots would instead start t=
o
move towards the center of the arena. That said, the weapon based
objecti=
ves were clear to me, and seemed to work as expected.

Lastly, I think that=
 the numbers shown during evolution are a bit
confusing. For example, at so=
me point I had something like a 'Best Fitness'
of 1049, an 'Evolution' of +=
623 and a 'Keep distance' of 5115, and I had no
clue how those numbers were=
 supposed to relate to each other. I mean, my
fitness wasn't improving by +=
623 because my previous fitness was also
around 1000, and I didn't know how=
 a 'Keep distance' of 5115 would
translate to a fitness of 1049. I wonder i=
f there are ways to make these
numbers more intuitive.

That said, I did ha=
ve some fun with game (I managed to beat the final
boss), and I am looking =
forward to any updates and expansions, if they are
planned. Making a compel=
ling game based on evolutionary algorithms is a
difficult but interesting c=
hallenge, and this game provides a great start.

Best regards,
Joost Huizin=
ga


On Sun, Aug 10, 2014 at 6:03 PM, Sebastian Risi sebastian.risi@gmail.c=
om
[neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
>
> Hi all,
>
> I'm happy to ann=
ounce our new game Evolve, made by Daniel Jallov, a master
> student at ITU=
 supervised by myself and Julian Togelius.
>
> The game consists of two maj=
or parts: an evolution part where neural
> networks are evolved using NEAT,=
 and a battle part where players use the
> evolved networks to control thei=
r robots. The goal of the project is to
> investigate whether giving the pl=
ayer indirect control over the robot (by
> switching brains in battle) is a=
n engaging game mechanic and whether it
> makes sense to put the AI in the =
hands of the player.
>
> Check it out here: http://jallov.com/thesis/
>
> L=
ooking forward to your comments!
>
> Cheers,
> Sebastian
>
> From the webpa=
ge:
>
> "Evolve is a game about becoming the greatest robot trainer of all =
time.
> Your mission is to teach a simple robot how to fight and ultimately=
 take it
> to the Champion=E2=80=99s arena to battle against other trainers=
. To reach this
> goal, you must teach your robot how to move and how to fi=
ght, and you must
> have the tactical nouse to tell your robot what to do i=
n the heat of
> battle. Your robot will gradually become more advanced as y=
ou progress
> through the missions, and when the missions are completed you=
 will be ready
> to battle online against other players."
>
>
> --
> Dr. Se=
bastian Risi

<div dir=3D"ltr">Hello Sebastian and Julian,<div><br></div><div>First of al=
l, I think this game is a great idea and an impressive result! It is one of=
 those ideas that I always wanted to try, to test wether it is fun to play =
and to see what kind of innovations might be produced in the hands of a lar=
ge player base, but I never felt I had enough time, experience or motivatio=
n to start development.</div>
<div><br></div><div>As for my experience play=
ing the game, I think the tutorial messages were very good, but I couldn&#3=
9;t shake the feeling of being a bit lost on the brain training screen. I m=
ean, the game told me that I should evolve a brain to follow and a brain to=
 flee, but during training I got little feedback on if I was doing things r=
ight or not. Maybe it would help if you could select a target behavior duri=
ng training such that the game could give you better feedback on your progr=
ess.</div>
<div><br></div><div>Also, despite the tooltips, some of the obje=
ctives weren't very clear to me. For example, I am not sure what the ex=
act difference is between keeping a certain distance and reaching a certain=
 distance, nor how exactly this interacts with the '- Distance' sli=
der. For example, I assumed that keeping a distance of 1 meter would cause =
the robots to drive towards the target and stop at 1 meter distance, but lo=
oking at the results and numbers during evolution I am really not sure if t=
hat is true. Another example is the 'move around' objective. When I=
 tried to evolve a brain that would stand still and do nothing I set the &#=
39;move around' slider to -100. When I ran evolution, rather than stand=
ing still the robots would instead start to move towards the center of the =
arena. That said, the weapon based objectives were clear to me, and seemed =
to work as expected.</div>
<div><br></div><div>Lastly, I think that the num=
bers shown during evolution are a bit confusing. For example, at some point=
 I had something like a 'Best Fitness' of 1049, an 'Evolution&#=
39; of +623 and a 'Keep distance' of 5115, and I had no clue how th=
ose numbers were supposed to relate to each other. I mean, my fitness wasn&=
#39;t improving by +623 because my previous fitness was also around 1000, a=
nd I didn't know how a 'Keep distance' of 5115 would translate =
to a fitness of 1049. I wonder if there are ways to make these numbers more=
 intuitive.</div>
<div><br></div><div>That said, I did have some fun with g=
ame (I managed to beat the final boss), and I am looking forward to any upd=
ates and expansions, if they are planned. Making a compelling game based on=
 evolutionary algorithms is a difficult but interesting challenge, and this=
 game provides a great start.</div>
<div><br></div><div>Best regards,</div>=

      <p></p><div dir=
=3D"ltr">Hi all,<br><br>I'm happy to announce our new game Evolve, made=
 by Daniel Jallov, a master student at ITU supervised by myself and Julian =
Togelius.<br><br>The game consists of two major parts: an evolution part wh=
ere neural networks are evolved using NEAT, and a battle part where players=
 use the evolved networks to control their robots. The goal of the project =
is to investigate whether giving the player indirect control over the robot=
 (by switching brains in battle) is an engaging game mechanic and whether i=
t makes sense to put the AI in the hands of the player.<br>

<br>Check it o=
ut here: <a href=3D"http://jallov.com/thesis/" target=3D"_blank">http://jal=
lov.com/thesis/</a><br><br>Looking forward to your comments!<br><br>Cheers,=
<br>Sebastian<br><br>From the webpage:<br><br>"Evolve is a game about =
becoming the greatest robot trainer of all time. Your mission is to teach a=
 simple robot how to fight and ultimately take it to the Champion=E2=80=99s=
 arena to battle against other trainers. To reach this goal, you must teach=
 your robot how to move and how to fight, and you must have the tactical no=
use to tell your robot what to do in the heat of battle. Your robot will gr=
adually become more advanced as you progress through the missions, and when=
 the missions are completed you will be ready to battle online against othe=
r players."<br>

<br><br>--<br>Dr. Sebastian Risi<br>Assistant Profess=
or<br>IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D08<br>Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300=
